byline.contributor: Binyamin Appelbaum contributed reporting from Washington.

abstract: Federal Reserve officials, hesitating about raising interest rates during shaky world economy, recall situation in 1994 and 1995 when series of rate increases put pressure on Mexico and other emerging markets.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, a series of rate increases by the Federal Reserve put pressure on emerging markets like Mexico, which had to be bailed out by the United States and the I.M.F. Could it happen again?

headline.main: Watching the Fed, and Remembering the Tequila Crisis
headline.print_headline: Watching the Fed on Rates, and Remembering the Tequila Crisis

snippet: Twenty years ago, a series of rate increases by the Federal Reserve put pressure on emerging markets like Mexico, which had to be bailed out by the United States and the I.M.F. Could it happen again?
